linkTarget.anchoringText: SRV is a very well over stretched concept during last 3 to 4 years by applying the "Barnett SRV concept" to all kinds of shale reservoirs and even tight sand oil as well regardless. It may be the time to re-think and reevaluated this "hot concept", and to take reasonable precautions. The true SRV should be related to the production for a reservoir fracturing job. If it is not, it should be called the seismic event volume rather than the stimulated volume. From Figure 1 SRV of a horizontal well is on the left, and the Active Production Volume (APV) is shown on the right. Notice the APV is 40% less than the SRV (Vermilye et al. 2016).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: The Stimulated Reservoir Volume (left) and the Active Production Volume (right) (Vermilye et al. 2016)

formatted-caption.caption-text: The Stimulated Reservoir Volume (left) and the Active Production Volume (right) (Vermilye et al. 2016)

linkTarget.bib:
Vermilye et al., 2016 Vermilye, J. Vermilye , and Sicking, C. Sicking
2016. Microseismic Maps Production Volume. THE AMERICAN OIL & GAS REPORTER , January 2016, http://www.globalgeophysical.com/docs/AOGR%20Jan%202016%20Production%20Monitoring.pdf (accessed June 27 2016).

linkTarget.anchoringText: While the microseismic map was complete, the microseismic event map has been displayed corresponding with time. This is the final result from the SRV monitoring. However from the studied cases, the microseismic events observed in real time for a vertical well have reached the maximum area of SRV with about just 1/5 of the total fracturing fluid volume injected, which means during the pad injection. Fracture length, width and height did not change with the injection of proppant after pad injection (Figure 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Microseismic Event Cloud (left) fracture geometry vs injected volume (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microseismic Event Cloud (left) fracture geometry vs injected volume (right)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Further, in a horizontal well fracturing case, from a real time microseismic monitoring, we can see that the microseismic event cloud had already reached the maximum SRV area for most frac stage at the pad phase (Figure 3). During proppant injection phase, the fracture almost did not grow anywhere.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Microseismic event cloud for horizontal well 11 stages, pad stage (left) proppant stage (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microseismic event cloud for horizontal well 11 stages, pad stage (left) proppant stage (right)

linkTarget.anchoringText: From the production and the SRV, the normalized production rate corresponding with the SRV is plotted in Figure 4. There is no obvious correlation between the SRV and the current and the first 4 month production. Hence a larger Microseismic event SRV do not corresponds with better production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Normalized oil rate vs SRV for the current (right) and the first 4 months average (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Normalized oil rate vs SRV for the current (right) and the first 4 months average (right)

linkTarget.anchoringText: As we have seen above that the SRV shows a very weak correlation with the oil production rates even at the early production time in that field. We have made correlation between the oil production rates verse proppant volume and the amount of fluid, and we also see weak corrections between them. A normalized oil production rate for different total liquid volume and the total proppant volume injected are used for both cases (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Normalized oil rate vs total proppant injected (left), normalized oil rate vs frac fluid injected (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Normalized oil rate vs total proppant injected (left), normalized oil rate vs frac fluid injected (right)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: normalized oil rate vs frac fluid injected

linkTarget.anchoringText: When we look at those correction between the rate vs inject proppant volume and total fluid in Eagle Ford shale oil reservoir, the oil production rates verse proppant amount also show a weak correlation but it shows relative stronger than correction between the rate with injected total fluid generated using Big Data methodology (Gao et al, 2013), as shown in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: BOED peak rate vs injected proppant (left), rate vs injected fluid volume (right) (Gao et al, 2013)

formatted-caption.caption-text: BOED peak rate vs injected proppant (left), rate vs injected fluid volume (right) (Gao et al, 2013)

linkTarget.bib:
Gao et al., 2013 Gao
C. Gao , and Gao, H. Gao
2013. Evaluating Early-Time Eagle Ford Well Performance Using Multivariate Adaptive Regression Splines (MARS). Paper SPE-166462 presented at SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition, New Orleans, Louisiana, USA , 30 September-2 October.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Basic rock geomechanics properties and formation permeability are the foundation for fracturing design and optimization regardless large scale or small scale with high pumping rate or low pumping rate. In-situ horizontal stress differential, dynamic and static Young's modulus correction, Poisson's ratio, toughness, brittleness index and etc. each of these parameters should be characterized carefully. For Fuyu formation, the in-situ horizontal stress differential ranges from 8.5 to 9 Mpa; brittleness coefficient is between 40% to 60%; Stress shadow and fracture interferences are also detected through down hole pressure gages and the simulated results also shows the similarity as field monitored. Fracture surrounding stress field is changed while the fracture is propped open. It is known as the stress shadowing effect. The most impact from this effect is to the fracture length and orientation. In this simulate cases minim cluster spacing is 30 m as shown in Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Cluster spacing effects the stress field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cluster spacing effects the stress field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 8 describes the simulated formation radial permeability and vertical permeability influence on the daily oil production. From the plot, the radial permeability have more influence on the daily oil production; vertical permeability has a certain impact on daily oil production but only in a small portion. Hence vertical permeability is one of the primary factors for production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Daily oil production Vs permeability A: radial permeability. B: vertical permeability

formatted-caption.caption-text: Daily oil production Vs permeability A: radial permeability. B: vertical permeability

linkTarget.anchoringText: The heterogeneity formation in the lateral part of the horizontal well is the primary factor that determines the design of distance of fracture stages and clusters. The homogeneity formation study presented some insight of fracture cluster designs. However the studied formation has the permeability from 0.1 to 1mD. So the comprehensive design for different section in the horizontal well lateral is needed to achieve the economic efficiency. Figure 9 shows the cluster spacing index for different permeability. When consider formation K is at 0.7mD, as probability 50%, from the reservoir fluid flow view requires about 27 m cluster spacing, which is close to 30 m in stress shadow calculation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Cluster spacing index for different permeability

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cluster spacing index for different permeability

linkTarget.anchoringText: Production over time was calculated. From Figure 10 the predicted production has a perfect match with the actual production rate. The success of production rate simulation empowers the operator to estimate the production profile of the wells and a more precise economical evaluation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Curve of production rate and cumulative production. The black line is the simulated production rate, and the green line is the actual production rate.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Curve of production rate and cumulative production. The black line is the simulated production rate, and the green line is the actual production rate.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A hybrid fracturing treatment fluid was applied. From a full 3-D design simulation, the proppant distributions are presented in Figure 11. A: Slick water with larger proppant, proppant covers shorter distance, and settles at the bottom of the fracture. B: Slick water with smaller proppant, proppant covers longer distance, but mostly distributed at the bottom of the fracture. C: cross linker gel with smaller proppant, the proppant coverage length does not increase by much, but the proppant distribution covers the fracture primary area. The fracture is effectively propped to maintain the conductivity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Proppant distribution for different designs. A: slick water + large proppant, B: slick water + small proppant, C: cross linker gel + small proppant

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant distribution for different designs. A: slick water + large proppant, B: slick water + small proppant, C: cross linker gel + small proppant

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 shows the impact of different fracture permeability on daily oil production. This data is based on 360 days of production. From the plot, for low permeability, larger radius yields a better daily production, and the daily production for high permeability has a peak value. Therefore, for low permeability reservoir, with the proper fracture conductivity, increase in fracture length has the positive effect to production; for the medium and high permeability formation, within the appropriate fracture radius, increase fracture conductivity will achieve better production effect.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Daily oil production Vs fracture radius for different permeability of 1mD and 20 mD

formatted-caption.caption-text: Daily oil production Vs fracture radius for different permeability of 1mD and 20 mD

linkTarget.anchoringText: The slick water could control the fracture height and length effectively. Figure 13 shows the fracture difference between slick water and the gel. Figure 13 A is the fracture created with slick water, B is the fracture created with gel. Slick water could controls the fracture grown in length instead of in height. As discussed in earlier section, long fracture length has the positive effect for lower permeability reservoir development. Additionally, the color in Figure 13 represents the proppant distribution condition. The warm color indicates higher proppant coverage, where the cold color represents low proppant coverage. The

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of slick water and gel as fracturing fluid. A: fracture with slick water, B: fracture with gel

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of slick water and gel as fracturing fluid. A: fracture with slick water, B: fracture with gel

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 shows the impact of different proportion of prepad fluid to the fracture. Prepad volume for this simulation has been set at 40% 60% and 80%. A total of 1000m3 of fracturing fluid was applied for all simulations. From the fracture length comparison, 60% prepad volume created the longest fracture half length.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Fracture length with different proportion of fracturing fluid, A: prepad volume is 40%, B: prepad volume is 60%, C: prepad volume is 80%

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fracture length with different proportion of fracturing fluid, A: prepad volume is 40%, B: prepad volume is 60%, C: prepad volume is 80%

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 15, different volume of fracturing fluid was compared. In this comparison, the prepad proportion has been set at 60%. The result shows that the slick water creates better fracture half length, and the primary proppant has distributed with in the formation layer. However, when the volume of total fluid injected is greater than 1000m3, the fracture length does not grow significantly.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Fracture proppant coverage for different volume of fracturing fluid used. A: 500m3 of fracturing fluid was injected, the fracture length is 220m; B: 250m3 of fluid was injected, the fracture length is 75m; C: 1000m3 of fluid was injected, fracture length is 380m; D: 1500m3 of fluid was injected, fracture length is 420m

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fracture proppant coverage for different volume of fracturing fluid used. A: 500m3 of fracturing fluid was injected, the fracture length is 220m; B: 250m3 of fluid was injected, the fracture length is 75m; C: 1000m3 of fluid was injected, fracture length is 380m; D: 1500m3 of fluid was injected, fracture length is 420m

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: 250m3 of fluid was injected, the fracture length is 75m

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition, more total pumping volume would increases the fracture network complexity and the drainage area. It improves the oil recovery in a certain range. From the studied well, the relation between complex fracture length and the fluid volume is displayed in Figure 16. The peak value for the ultimate fluid volume is between 1000 to 1300m3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Complex fracture length vs. fluid volume

formatted-caption.caption-text: Complex fracture length vs. fluid volume
